utterances: The whole city will be absolutely crowded next week especially on Wednesday with festivals, singers, and so on, and so on.
So the whole city will be more or less boiling of joy.
For a 300-year-old guy, Linnaeus still has a big influence.
For one, he developed our system for naming organisms, the binomial system - two words -like homo sapiens.
He grouped these organisms: birds by their beaks, insects by their wings.
And then he ranked the groups: class, order, genus, species.
Even today, high school students are learning the mnemonics for these ranks.
The ranking system has more or less survived 300 years.
Its structure is still sound, but just like a 300-year-old house, it's required some renovation.
To see why, I visited Kevin de Queiroz.
Where is the light?
De Queiroz is a zoologist for the Smithsonian here in Washington.
He curates the reptiles and amphibian collection in the basement of the museum of Natural History, and it's huge.
Every time you turn on the light I see another mile of reptiles.
This is probably the largest collection of amphibians and reptiles in the world.
Five hundred and sixty thousand jars.
Each holds a different species or reptile or amphibian floating in alcohol.
So as we're walking down this hall, we have the lizards on your left...
The scientists who organized this collection grouped the animals by morphology: the structure of their tongues, the shape of their skulls, whether or not their jaws come apart.
But now, we get to the end here, and now we've got a, sort of, mixture of weird snakes and lizard-like things that we don't really know where they fit in.
De Queiroz calls this the mystery aisle; the lizards and snakes on these shelves are just too weird to be sorted by their scales and skulls.
Here are the Amphisbaenia.
De Queiroz pulls a jar out off the top shelf, opens it up, and tugs at this long thing.
And you can see sometimes the way they were folded doesn't exactly fit well into the - yeah, so you might see why they call that worm a lizard.
It's like a giant, bloated earthworm with scales.
Today is a big day for the Amphisbaenians.
Until recently, no one knew where they fit on the reptilian tree of life.
But now, scientists have a new tool.
They look at the species' DNA.
It turns out that Amphisbaenians share a lot of DNA with some pretty, typical-looking lizards with feet that live in the U.S.
and Europe.
Well, so now, now that we have a better idea about who they're related to, we should probably rearrange the collection so that they're close to the things that they're closely related to.
In cases like this, DNA analysis is shaking up the tree of life, moving creatures from one branch to another.
Other times, DNA studies help create new branches altogether.
Linnaeus grouped all of life into four different ranks.
Now, De Queiroz says, scientists use dozens.
As we've discovered more and more about how things are related to each other, seven ranks just weren't enough to deal with it.
So now, you know, we have super-orders, sub-families, super-families, tribes.
It turns out life is even more complicated than Linnaeus thought.
But, De Queiroz says, Linnaeus got one thing perfectly right.
He looked around him and saw that there is order in nature.
And Darwin agreed with him a hundred years later.
If he hadn't, we might not be celebrating Linnaeus today.
Addie Goss, NPR News, Washington.
According to Denver police, the shooting followed a dispute between Broncos teammates and others at a nightclub after the Broncos' last game of the season.
We are joined now from Bronco headquarters in Englewood, Colorado, by Preston Parsons, he is back up quarterback with the Broncos, and Bill Rader, the team chaplain.
Welcome to you both.
Thank you.
Hello.
And I'm very sorry for you lost.
Thank you.
Preston, can you tell us more about you've heard about what happened before the shooting?
They got in their limousines and they left, and apparently whoever this person was had a different idea and followed the limo.
Preston, as word of what happened circulated, what does the team do?
What do you do when something like this happen?
And we'll roll to our next political story.

With just a little over one week to go before the midterm elections, there are an abundance of polls on House and Senate races, voter turnout, the strength of the Tea Party and trends in early voting.
You name it and you can bet that some pollster is tracking it.
We turn now to someone who's been described as the pollsters' pollster because of his ability to crunch data in new ways, and because of his knack for making razor-sharp predictions.
We're talking about Nate Silver, the statistician whos founded a blog called FiveThirthyEight which, by the way, is the total number of Electoral College votes.
Nate Silver, welcome to the program.
Yeah, thank you.
With just a week to go, are there any trends in particular that we should be noting in these final days?

You know, I think it's actually been quite flat overall, where since Labor Day or so, I think you kind of know the rules of the game, so to speak; which that Democrats will not be given credit for having righted the economy; the Republicans will benefit a lot from that.
Now, you know, knowing the rules of the game doesnt mean it can't played out in different ways.
But it's an unfavorable climate to Democrats and it seems like its been fairly stable, frankly, over the past month, month and a half.
And I guess thats good news for Republicans because their strategy is basically to hold on to the ball and run down the clock.
Yeah, thats right, to use the kind of sports metaphor.
But certainly in the House they look they're the clear favorites to pick up a majority of seats.
We think it's most likely to be about 50, it could be more.
It could be 60 or 70.
It could be fewer, which means Democrats would retain control, I think it's about a one in five chance.
In the Senate, though, Republicans still need to find one or two more states where they can notch a win.
It looks like they have a pretty clear path to 49 or 50.
They would need 51 though because otherwise you'd have a 50/50 split, and Joe Biden, the vice president, would break the tie.
So they need to win a state in blue territory.
You know, if they only, quote-unquote, won eight or nine Senate seats, thats still a terrific year by kind of any usual standard.
Nate Silver, you took a bold step over the weekend with a forecast that diminished the Republicans' chances for taking over the Senate, as you noted.
Whats that based on?
Well, the Senate is a lot easier to kind of get a handle on than the House, where you have 12, 14 competitive Senate seats versus a hundred or so in the House.
What we see is Republicans kind of stuck on about a potential 50-seat gain but they haven't quite gotten California, for instance, to the point where it's a toss-up.
Or Washington state, they could still lose.
So, you know, they kind of have to flip the coin four times and have it come up heads kind of four times in a row to take the Senate.
What are you predicting in the 37 states with gubernatorial races right now?
Well, we think overall, at the end of November 2nd, you'll have Republicans with control of 30 of the 50 states.
So that would count since they already would carry over from the previous election.
But they figure to win the majority of open seat races on election night.
They should probably retain all of their incumbents.
They will probably beat a couple of Democratic incumbents, like in Iowa.
I mean, you know, there will be some silver linings for Democrats.
In the gubernatorial races, theyll probably win some of the large states.
For instance, California looks good for them.
Theyll certainly win here in New York, I would think.
But overall, especially in the Midwest, youd have Republicans kind of winning the majority or poised to the win the majority of those races.
And so the trend you see in the congressional races will kind of carry over to governors' races and also to statehouses, where you have Democratic legislatures being ousted by Republican ones.
And theyll have control over redistricting and kind of policy at the state level for the next couple of years.
In some of these states, there are still a large number of undecided voters.
What accounts for that and where are they trending?
Well, this late in the race - I mean, early in the race if you have undecided voters, it's usually because they aren't familiar with the candidates.
Right?
This late in the race it means they are familiar with the candidates and dont like them.

But usually, you know, it's kind of if you have, you know, 15 percent undecideds this late in the race it kind of means that both parties have kind of failed to nominate the right candidates, and could have won that race if they'd picked a better one.
